figure_1.title: FIGURE 1.
figure_1.caption: Ice crystal formation and artifactual retinal detachment in frozen pig eye during sectioning. (a) Image of a pig eye frozen in optimal cutting temperature embedding media and mounted in a cryostat for sectioning. (b) Ice crystals are observed in the vitreous immediately after 25 μm section was cut and mounted on a glass slide (arrows). (c) A few seconds later, the same slide shows artifactual detachment of the retina (arrows).

figure_2.title: FIGURE 2.
figure_2.caption: Fixation of large eyes for frozen sections. Enucleated eyes are fixed in either 10% formalin or 4% PFA at room temperature (RT) for 4–6 h, followed by removal of muscle, adipose, and connective tissue resulting in clean sclera (a). Eyes are incubated in fixative for an additional 12 h at room temperature, placed on a flat surface and a trephine is used to remove the cornea (b). The eye is immersed in fixative, incubated at 4°C overnight, and then the lens, iris and zonules are removed (c). Under a dissecting microscope, fixative is injected into the vitreous through a 23‐gauge needle to disrupt the vitreous, and the fixative‐filled eyecup is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (d).

figure_3.title: FIGURE 3.
figure_3.caption: Cryopreservation, vitreous replacement, and embedding of a large eye for frozen sections. (a) After fixation, the two‐step process of cryopreservation begins by visualizing the eyecup under a dissecting microscope and injecting a solution of 15% sucrose/phosphate‐buffered saline (PBS) into the vitreous to disrupt it. The eyecup filled with 15% sucrose/PBS is returned to 4°C for 12 h. The second step of cryopreservation is initiated by injecting 30% sucrose/PBS into the vitreous and combining fluid‐based dissection with mechanical dissection with scissors to remove all of the vitreous followed by incubation of the eyecup filled with 30% sucrose/PBS at 4°C for 12 h. (b) A 10 mL syringe is filled with OCT compound, the 30% sucrose/PBS is removed from the eyecup, and OCT is slowly injected completely filling the eyecup. (c) The eyecup is placed in a mold made of aluminum foil, additional OCT is injected to submerge the eyecup, and it is frozen at −80°C overnight.

figure_4.title: FIGURE 4.
figure_4.caption: Cryosections of ex vivo pig eye after suprachoroidal injection of India ink. Enucleated pig eyes were given a suprachoroidal injection of 200 μL of India ink and then fixed, cryopreserved and embedded in OCT as described in text. (a) An image of the frozen tissue block in the cryostat shows the structure of the eye well‐maintained with homogeneous embedding medium without ice crystals in the vitreous cavity and India ink visualized in the suprachoroidal space (SCS) around the circumference of the eye. (b) Light micrograph of a 25 μm frozen section shows good maintenance of the shape and structure of the eye with India ink marking the expanded suprachoroidal space. High magnification views from different parts of the eye shows intact unstained retina despite 48 h of postmortem time prior to fixation (c, d).

figure_5.title: FIGURE 5.
figure_5.caption: Ocular sections of minipig and monkey eyes after suprachoroidal injection of a green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression plasmid, pCAG‐GFP‐Z1. Göttingen minipigs and a rhesus monkey were given a suprachoroidal injection of 50 μL of polymeric nanoparticles containing 0.33 μg/μL CAG‐GFP‐Z1 plasmid. After 2 weeks, the eyes were prepared for frozen sections as described in the text and 25 μm frozen sections were examined by fluorescence microscopy. (a) A low power view of a transverse ocular frozen section through the equator of the minipig eye shows the shape of the eye is well‐maintained and there is fluorescence around the entire circumference. High magnification of the fluorescence image alone (b) or merged with light microscopic image to show nuclear staining with Hoechst 33258 (c), illustrate good retinal morphology with fluorescence in multiple layers of the retina (d–f). Some sections were immunohistochemically stained with anti‐GFP antibody and a representative section is shown confirming that the fluorescence is due to GFP expression (e). A transverse frozen section from the monkey eye illustrates GFP fluorescence in the sclera, RPE, and inner segments of photoreceptors (g). Cone matrix sheaths stained with rhodamine‐labeled peanut agglutinin surround GFP in cone inner segments and illustrate excellent cone morphology (h, i). GCL, ganglion cell layer; IPL, inner plexiform layer; INL, inner nuclear layer; IS/OS, inner segment/outer segment; ONL, outer nuclear layer; OPL, outer plexiform layer; RPE, retinal pigment epithelium.

figure_6.title: FIGURE 6.
figure_6.caption: Immunostaining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and histochemical staining with peanut agglutinin (PNA) in rabbit frozen ocular sections and human eyes. Ocular frozen sections from rabbit eyes processed as described in the text were immunostained for GFAP and histochemically stained with rhodamine‐labeled PNA. (a) Green channel shows GFAP‐stained glial cells in the inner retina. (b) Red channel shows PNA‐stained cone matrix sheaths surrounding cone photoreceptors. (c) Merging of the fluorescence images and a light micrograph of Hoechst‐stained nuclei illustrate excellent retinal morphology. A postmortem human eye was placed in fixative 48 h after death and processed as described in the text. Frozen sections were stained with rhodamine‐labeled PNA and counterstained with Hoechst. Low power (d) and high power (e) images show excellent preservation of retinal morphology with blue stained nuclei in the INL and ONL with red‐stained cone matrix sheath adjacent to the ONL. GCL, ganglion cell layer; IPL, inner plexiform layer; INL, inner nuclear layer; IS/OS, inner segment/outer segment; ONL, outer nuclear layer; OPL, outer plexiform layer; RPE, retinal pigment epithelium.

claims.sentence:
Preparation of eyes for frozen sections
Figure 1a shows a block of a pig eye that underwent a preservation process involving fixation and freezing in OCT compound, without replacement of the vitreous.
Immediately after sectioning and placing the sample on a glass slide, ice crystals can be seen in the vitreous (Figure 1b).
After mounting a frozen section on a glass slide, we observed the vitreous slowly separating from the retina while thawing causing an artifactual retinal detachment (Figure 1c).

Open in a new tab
Ice crystal formation and artifactual retinal detachment in frozen pig eye during sectioning. (a) Image of a pig eye frozen in optimal cutting temperature embedding media and mounted in a cryostat for sectioning. (b) Ice crystals are observed in the vitreous immediately after 25 μm section was cut and mounted on a glass slide (arrows). (c) A few seconds later, the same slide shows artifactual detachment of the retina (arrows).Immediately after enucleation, the eye is immersed in formalin or PFA for 4–6 h at room temperature followed by removal of adipose and connective tissue (Figure 2a).
The globe then is placed on a flat surface and a trephine is used to remove an 11.5 mm diameter circle of the cornea (Figure 2b).
After incubation in fixative at 4°C overnight, the iris, lens, and zonules are removed (Figure 2c).
The fixative‐filled eyecup still containing vitreous is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 2d).

The infusion‐based vitreous disruption is repeated with PBS/30% sucrose in combination with mechanical dissection using surgical scissors to remove the remaining vitreous, followed by incubation at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 3a).
The sucrose solution is removed from the eyecup and it is filled with an OCT embedding medium ensuring the exclusion of air bubbles (Figure 3b).
The eyecup is placed in a mold, submerged in OCT, and frozen overnight at −80°C (Figure 3c).
Under a dissecting microscope, fixative is injected into the vitreous through a 23‐gauge needle to disrupt the vitreous, and the fixative‐filled eyecup is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (d).FIGURE 3.

Photographs of the partially sectioned eyecup in the cryostat show India ink in the suprachoroid with an overlying retina attached and homogenous OCT with no ice crystals in the vitreous cavity (Figure 4a).
Overlapped images taken by light microscopy show India ink evenly distributed in the suprachoroidal space around the entire circumference of the eye (Figure 4b).
Sections examined in low and high‐power views, show India ink in the suprachoroid space with the overlying retina intact (low‐power view, Figure 4c, and high‐power view, 4d).

A low‐power view of a transverse ocular section through the equator of the eye shows the maintenance of its shape and structure with GFP expression in the retina around the circumference of the eye (Figure 5a).
High magnification shows green fluorescence in well‐preserved photoreceptors and some cells in the inner retina (Figure 5b,c).
Frozen sections immunohistochemically stained for GFP have a red reaction product that colocalizes with the green fluorescence indicating that the fluorescence is due to GFP expression (Figure 5d–f).
A transverse frozen section from the monkey eye illustrates GFP fluorescence in the sclera, RPE, and inner segments of photoreceptors (Figure 5g).
Rhodamine‐labeled peanut agglutinin staining highlights cone matrix sheaths surrounding GFP in cone inner segments, demonstrating exceptional cone morphology (Figure 5h,i).
Fluorescence microscopy with the green channel shows glial cells predominantly in the inner retina (Figure 6a), and the red channel shows cone matrix sheaths (Figure 6b).

Merging of the fluorescence images and a light micrograph of Hoechst‐stained nuclei illustrates excellent retinal morphology with GFAP‐stained glia in the inner retina and PNA‐stained photoreceptors in the outer retina (Figure 6c).
Low (Figure 6d) and high magnification (Figure 6e) images show preserved retinal morphology with clear resolution of cone matrix sheaths.4.

In addition, when frozen sections are mounted on the slides, the rapid thawing of the ice crystal causes the vitreous to contract, which often creates traction on the retina resulting in artifactual retinal detachments (Figure 1).

Retinal morphology is compromised by the delay between death and fixation of eyes obtained from an abattoir, but the procedure allows sufficient preservation of ocular structure and compartments to demonstrate that the ink remains confined in the suprachoroidal space but extends around the entire circumference of the eye (Figure 4).

After suprachoroidal injection of a NP vector containing a GFP expression plasmid, the procedure allows precise mapping of the extent of expression throughout the retina including cellular localization with excellent preservation of cellular structure allowing localization of reporter with cellular compartments (Figure 5).

Compared with other embedding approaches, frozen sections tend to provide superior antigen preservation and reactivity, but often sacrifice cellular structure, but with this procedure, both are maintained (Figure 6).
Human eyes provide one of the biggest challenges regarding maintenance of good cellular morphology in images obtained from frozen sections and the procedure overcomes this challenge (Figure 6).

Photographs of the partially sectioned eyecup in the cryostat show India ink in the suprachoroid with an overlying retina attached and homogenous OCT with no ice crystals in the vitreous cavity (Figure 4a).
Overlapped images taken by light microscopy show India ink evenly distributed in the suprachoroidal space around the entire circumference of the eye (Figure 4b).
Sections examined in low and high‐power views, show India ink in the suprachoroid space with the overlying retina intact (low‐power view, Figure 4c, and high‐power view, 4d).

A low‐power view of a transverse ocular section through the equator of the eye shows the maintenance of its shape and structure with GFP expression in the retina around the circumference of the eye (Figure 5a).
High magnification shows green fluorescence in well‐preserved photoreceptors and some cells in the inner retina (Figure 5b,c).
Frozen sections immunohistochemically stained for GFP have a red reaction product that colocalizes with the green fluorescence indicating that the fluorescence is due to GFP expression (Figure 5d–f).
A transverse frozen section from the monkey eye illustrates GFP fluorescence in the sclera, RPE, and inner segments of photoreceptors (Figure 5g).
Rhodamine‐labeled peanut agglutinin staining highlights cone matrix sheaths surrounding GFP in cone inner segments, demonstrating exceptional cone morphology (Figure 5h,i).
Fluorescence microscopy with the green channel shows glial cells predominantly in the inner retina (Figure 6a), and the red channel shows cone matrix sheaths (Figure 6b).

Merging of the fluorescence images and a light micrograph of Hoechst‐stained nuclei illustrates excellent retinal morphology with GFAP‐stained glia in the inner retina and PNA‐stained photoreceptors in the outer retina (Figure 6c).
Low (Figure 6d) and high magnification (Figure 6e) images show preserved retinal morphology with clear resolution of cone matrix sheaths.4.

In addition, when frozen sections are mounted on the slides, the rapid thawing of the ice crystal causes the vitreous to contract, which often creates traction on the retina resulting in artifactual retinal detachments (Figure 1).

Retinal morphology is compromised by the delay between death and fixation of eyes obtained from an abattoir, but the procedure allows sufficient preservation of ocular structure and compartments to demonstrate that the ink remains confined in the suprachoroidal space but extends around the entire circumference of the eye (Figure 4).

After suprachoroidal injection of a NP vector containing a GFP expression plasmid, the procedure allows precise mapping of the extent of expression throughout the retina including cellular localization with excellent preservation of cellular structure allowing localization of reporter with cellular compartments (Figure 5).

Compared with other embedding approaches, frozen sections tend to provide superior antigen preservation and reactivity, but often sacrifice cellular structure, but with this procedure, both are maintained (Figure 6).
Human eyes provide one of the biggest challenges regarding maintenance of good cellular morphology in images obtained from frozen sections and the procedure overcomes this challenge (Figure 6).

Preparation of eyes for frozen sections
Figure 1a shows a block of a pig eye that underwent a preservation process involving fixation and freezing in OCT compound, without replacement of the vitreous.
Immediately after sectioning and placing the sample on a glass slide, ice crystals can be seen in the vitreous (Figure 1b).
After mounting a frozen section on a glass slide, we observed the vitreous slowly separating from the retina while thawing causing an artifactual retinal detachment (Figure 1c).

Open in a new tab
Ice crystal formation and artifactual retinal detachment in frozen pig eye during sectioning. (a) Image of a pig eye frozen in optimal cutting temperature embedding media and mounted in a cryostat for sectioning. (b) Ice crystals are observed in the vitreous immediately after 25 μm section was cut and mounted on a glass slide (arrows). (c) A few seconds later, the same slide shows artifactual detachment of the retina (arrows).Immediately after enucleation, the eye is immersed in formalin or PFA for 4–6 h at room temperature followed by removal of adipose and connective tissue (Figure 2a).
The globe then is placed on a flat surface and a trephine is used to remove an 11.5 mm diameter circle of the cornea (Figure 2b).
After incubation in fixative at 4°C overnight, the iris, lens, and zonules are removed (Figure 2c).
The fixative‐filled eyecup still containing vitreous is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 2d).

The infusion‐based vitreous disruption is repeated with PBS/30% sucrose in combination with mechanical dissection using surgical scissors to remove the remaining vitreous, followed by incubation at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 3a).
The sucrose solution is removed from the eyecup and it is filled with an OCT embedding medium ensuring the exclusion of air bubbles (Figure 3b).
The eyecup is placed in a mold, submerged in OCT, and frozen overnight at −80°C (Figure 3c).
Under a dissecting microscope, fixative is injected into the vitreous through a 23‐gauge needle to disrupt the vitreous, and the fixative‐filled eyecup is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (d).FIGURE 3.

Sections examined in low and high‐power views, show India ink in the suprachoroid space with the overlying retina intact (low‐power view, Figure 4c, and high‐power view, 4d).

Figure 1a shows a block of a pig eye that underwent a preservation process involving fixation and freezing in OCT compound, without replacement of the vitreous.
Immediately after sectioning and placing the sample on a glass slide, ice crystals can be seen in the vitreous (Figure 1b).
After mounting a frozen section on a glass slide, we observed the vitreous slowly separating from the retina while thawing causing an artifactual retinal detachment (Figure 1c).
Immediately after enucleation, the eye is immersed in formalin or PFA for 4–6 h at room temperature followed by removal of adipose and connective tissue (Figure 2a).
The globe then is placed on a flat surface and a trephine is used to remove an 11.5 mm diameter circle of the cornea (Figure 2b).
After incubation in fixative at 4°C overnight, the iris, lens, and zonules are removed (Figure 2c).
The fixative‐filled eyecup still containing vitreous is incubated at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 2d).

The infusion‐based vitreous disruption is repeated with PBS/30% sucrose in combination with mechanical dissection using surgical scissors to remove the remaining vitreous, followed by incubation at 4°C for 12 h (Figure 3a).
The sucrose solution is removed from the eyecup and it is filled with an OCT embedding medium ensuring the exclusion of air bubbles (Figure 3b).
The eyecup is placed in a mold, submerged in OCT, and frozen overnight at −80°C (Figure 3c).

Photographs of the partially sectioned eyecup in the cryostat show India ink in the suprachoroid with an overlying retina attached and homogenous OCT with no ice crystals in the vitreous cavity (Figure 4a).
Overlapped images taken by light microscopy show India ink evenly distributed in the suprachoroidal space around the entire circumference of the eye (Figure 4b).
Sections examined in low and high‐power views, show India ink in the suprachoroid space with the overlying retina intact (low‐power view, Figure 4c, and high‐power view, 4d).

A low‐power view of a transverse ocular section through the equator of the eye shows the maintenance of its shape and structure with GFP expression in the retina around the circumference of the eye (Figure 5a).

Frozen sections immunohistochemically stained for GFP have a red reaction product that colocalizes with the green fluorescence indicating that the fluorescence is due to GFP expression (Figure 5d–f).
A transverse frozen section from the monkey eye illustrates GFP fluorescence in the sclera, RPE, and inner segments of photoreceptors (Figure 5g).
Rhodamine‐labeled peanut agglutinin staining highlights cone matrix sheaths surrounding GFP in cone inner segments, demonstrating exceptional cone morphology (Figure 5h,i).
